13.63.text: Today, we're on board the destroyer, HMAS Vampire.

17.20.text: Join us today for an in-depth look at this fantastic ship.

21.10.text: The Vampire is actually the second Vampire that was built

23.53.text: to continue the name made famous by the VMW-class destroyer.

27.40.text: The first Vampire and her sister ships

32.17.text: so named by the Germans in reference to their age and condition.

35.47.text: The second Vampire was commissioned to the Royal Australian Navy

45.57.text: after a flying vampire bat insignia

47.33.text: perched on the aft funnel on the ship.

49.97.text: Underneath the insignia is the Latin motto, audamus,

53.23.text: which translates as, "let us be daring" -

55.77.text: a great pun, considering the ship being Daring-class.

75.83.text: Here we are now on the bridge of the ship.

78.10.text: Now it was from the bridge that the Big Three were conducted.

80.73.text: That is, the safety of the ship, the navigation,

84.50.text: Now this actual ship, until the refit in 1970,

87.63.text: was open and exposed to the elements.

89.67.text: Surrounding me, you can see various controls.

91.70.text: Taking pride of place in the centre here is the ship's compass.

94.93.text: Just to my right is the rudder indicator.

96.93.text: And across there, you can see the engine order equipment.

100.40.text: Another thing which is really interesting up on the bridge

104.70.text: of course used to actually identify submarines.

125.47.text: The wheelhouse, where the actual steering of the ship

127.43.text: is carried out, with orders coming from the bridge above.

130.90.text: As you can see, it's an incredibly well-protected environment.

149.03.text: We're here now at the nerve centre of the ship:

152.73.text: It was here during battlestations that the captain

154.90.text: would control and command the ship.

156.97.text: Some 22 personnel were present in this room,

159.73.text: including weapons and systems officers and radar specialists,

163.43.text: all with one clear aim in life:

165.50.text: to collate and gather tactical information

167.60.text: and react to any possible threat.

169.67.text: The room is absolutely full of equipment,

171.53.text: but some of the key things to point out.

174.00.text: Just to the left of me is the radar,

176.43.text: for reacting to any aerial threat.

179.20.text: Across to my right-hand side, we can see the submarine plotter.

182.13.text: And directly above that, the mortar controls

184.37.text: to react to any possible submarine threat.

187.40.text: Directly across from me, we've also got the surface plotter.

201.27.text: This area is where the radio operators

203.03.text: would maintain communications with other ships around the world.

206.03.text: Also, one of the other important tasks they had,

208.10.text: certainly from a morale point of view,

209.57.text: is to receive telegrams for the sailors.

224.47.text: The Daring-class destroyer design evolved in Britain

228.73.text: Requirements for a new fleet destroyer for the Royal Navy

231.20.text: saw the first of eight ships ordered in March 1945.

235.03.text: The Darings had a standard displacement of 2,800 tons,

238.80.text: which increased to 3,600 tons at full load.

242.13.text: The new ships were so far beyond accepted destroyer design

246.67.text: they should be classified as light cruisers.

248.97.text: The ship and her sisters were 120 meters long,

253.27.text: Her propulsion system consisted of two Foster Wheeler boilers,

256.80.text: feeding two English Electric gear turbines,

259.33.text: which provided 54,000 horsepower to two propeller shafts.

263.87.text: Vampire could sail at over 30 knots,

266.27.text: and had a range of 3,700 nautical miles at 20 knots.

270.50.text: Her standard ship's company consisted of 20 officers

273.33.text: and 300 sailors - quite a number for any destroyer.

287.07.text: We're very lucky now to be joined by Len.

288.70.text: Len, thanks ever so much for talking to us.

290.67.text: Now, you served on HMAS Vampire?

296.87.text: And your role on the ship was?

299.60.text: Fantastic. So, very apt, then - we're obviously in the gun bay.

302.30.text: We're in the right place, yeah.

303.57.text: Can you tell us a little bit about the gun bay, please, Len?

306.03.text: The gun bay, it's a very important part of the whole system,

309.97.text: because this is the transfer point of the ordnance,

312.73.text: from the fixed structure of the ship

313.97.text: to the moving structure of the turret.

316.03.text: Because the turret above is all attached to this,

318.37.text: so when this rotates - when the turret rotates,

322.97.text: So, you're getting the ordnance from the ship into the turret,

326.73.text: all hand-moved, until you're ready to load the guns

331.53.text: and then you've got these hoists here.

334.37.text: That's a hoist for the projectile to go up to the gun,

337.63.text: and another one behind here for the propellant,

340.53.text: which is cordite to go up to the gun.

342.73.text: So, it all has to be organised around these rings.

346.20.text: So, if you've got your back to the gun when you're taking

349.10.text: the ordnance out of the hoist from the magazine,

352.53.text: you turn back around, the gun's in a different position.

355.63.text: So, you have to put the ordnance the right way around,

359.37.text: They put a little cut-out on top, so you know which way

362.47.text: to put the ordnance in, so you don't get them back-to-front.

365.70.text: We were discussing briefly earlier on

367.70.text: about the fuses on the ammunition,

371.87.text: So, for example, the one at the moment on the platform there...

374.77.text: The one on the - ready in the hoist -

378.13.text: is what's called a timed mechanical.

380.30.text: It's got a clock fuse and you set it to so many seconds

383.73.text: to detonate after it leaves the barrel.

386.90.text: The other type is a direct action, which is this one -

393.20.text: And the third one, which we can't display

394.93.text: because the Navy wouldn't give us any,

399.73.text: It detonates 20 feet in front of a target.

410.47.text: Here we are in the turret, which is the end result

413.57.text: of what you were looking at in the gun bay,

416.80.text: where the ordnance comes up to the turret,

420.07.text: the propellant comes up in this hoist here

422.80.text: and the projectile comes up in this hoist.

426.73.text: Two loaders are here, that take the ordnance out of the hoist

430.27.text: and put them on the loading tray,

431.73.text: which is in front of us here.

434.07.text: The cordite goes on first, then the shell.

438.37.text: Once they're on, hands together and strike the rammer,

445.47.text: throws the ordnance up into the breech and shuts the breech.

449.47.text: When the gun fires, the gun recoils,

452.37.text: spits the empty out, and re-cocks the rammer.

457.63.text: Now, this happens every three and a half -

459.33.text: one every three and a half seconds -

461.90.text: which is quite a bit, when you consider

467.43.text: and the cordite weighs about 17 kilos.

471.57.text: Inside the turret is not actually noisy for the firing.

475.10.text: It certainly - it makes a lot of noise -

477.77.text: but the biggest amount of noise

479.37.text: is the hydraulic motors that run everything.

483.57.text: And when the empty goes into the bin,

486.83.text: which is in the centre of the gun bay,

489.03.text: that makes a lot of noise, as well.

507.07.text: This is the captain's day cabin,

508.80.text: and as you can see, it's full of home comforts,

511.00.text: something which the majority of the crew didn't have.

524.70.text: The ship's sick bay was incredibly well-stocked,

526.60.text: and of course it had to be to cover every eventuality.

546.67.text: As well as those four and a half inch guns,

548.57.text: Vampire also had other weaponry on board.

550.87.text: Behind me, we can see the Bofors anti-aircraft gun -

553.67.text: this particular one being the Mark V 40 millimetre.

557.77.text: It was an effective gun, with a maximum range of 2,500 meters

561.70.text: and a rate of fire of 140 rounds per minute.

565.73.text: HMAS Vampire served in the Royal Australian Navy

571.57.text: Despite her armament, Vampire had a peaceful career,

574.03.text: and was not involved in any combat.

580.30.text: held off Singapore during the Indonesian confrontation

583.13.text: with Malaysia in 1965 and offered gun support

586.83.text: while escorting troops to Vietnam in the 1960's.

590.53.text: In June 1970, she sailed into Williamstown Dockyard in Victoria

594.20.text: to undergo an extended refit as part of being paid off

599.17.text: She received new gun turrets and fire control systems,

602.50.text: new aircraft warning and navigation radar,

605.00.text: plus replacement of a major portion of her superstructure,

609.67.text: Her old funnels were replaced with new ones.

611.83.text: The pentad torpedo mount was removed and a new radar suite

614.93.text: was installed to stay relevant to changing times.

618.60.text: HMAS Vampire was decommissioned on the 13th of August, 1987,

623.77.text: after serving 27 years in the Royal Australian Navy

626.60.text: and clocking up in the region of 808 thousand nautical miles.

632.83.text: to the Australian National Maritime Museum,

635.00.text: to be preserved as a museum ship.
